text:
Hi, we're writing an exercise on regex for the upcoming Exercism version and could need some help testing it. I find it really hard to estimate how long it would take people to solve, and what parts in particular could cause issues.

I've already asked people who are quite experienced with regex to test it, so I'm mostly looking for people who are newish to using them (but not entirely new). It took the more experienced users ~8-10min on average.

If you have some time to help me out, I'd really appreciate if you could try coming up with an expression that captures the relevant info in the input strings, and let me know how long it took you and if there was anything in particular that caused issues.

Instructions are attached below, here's a regex101 link with test input: <https://regex101.com/r/vBAvfr/1/>

The final result should look roughly like the screenshot:

elements.text:
Hi, we're writing an exercise on regex for the upcoming Exercism version and could need some help testing it. I find it really hard to estimate how long it would take people to solve, and what parts in particular could cause issues.

I've already asked people who are quite experienced with regex to test it, so I'm mostly looking for people who are newish to using them (but not entirely new). It took the more experienced users ~8-10min on average.

If you have some time to help me out, I'd really appreciate if you could try coming up with an expression that captures the relevant info in the input strings, and let me know how long it took you and if there was anything in particular that caused issues.

Instructions are attached below, here's a regex101 link with test input:
The final result should look roughly like the screenshot:

text: What happens if a person is named (he/she)

elements.text: What happens if a person is named (he/she)

text:
Good question. Since the name is non-optional, the first occurance would be the name, I guess.

Only the cases in the test input need to be addressed. The justification in the "story" is that there's a limited amount of speakers and whoever wrote the list asked everyone for preferences beforehand. The script is also a one-off thing and doesn't necessarily need to address all potential edge cases, only the ones in the test input.

While we tried to cover a lot of common misconceptions about people (e.g. assuming ascii names etc) in those test cases, it's impossible to cover everything in an exercise, so there are still a bunch of assumptions that you can do that would not hold true for a general solution that would work on arbitrary lists.
